Award.AwardTitle: UNS: Dynamic Contact Line Region Heat Transfer and Interface Behavior at High Heat Fluxes Through a Controlled Oscillating Meniscus

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The principal investigator proposes to investigate the boiling phenomenon (much like boiling in a pan) when the surface temperature is exceedingly higher than boiling temperature. The result has many industrial applications including cooling powerful computer and supercomputer devices. The PI will also use liquids other than water that are commonly used in industrial cooling. Graduate students will be involved in the research activities. The PI will expand his current work with students in the 6th grade class from Franklin Roosevelt Middle School from the Rochester city school district serving minority and underprivileged students.

The evaporation of liquid film sandwiched between the vapor bubble and the solid surface (i.e., the meniscus) is responsible for the phase change. The PI will perform experiments, simulations and analytical studies on an evaporating meniscus in a pressure-controlled environment with three liquids and on different surfaces. The PI proposes boiling conditions up to CHF (critical heat flux) conditions. The intended results will provide quantitative data on (a) transient film thickness by capturing laser interference fringes at high temporal resolutions, (b) high-resolution transient thermal response of the underlying heater surface, and (c) contact angle and interface modulation with high speed imaging. The proposed tasks are important and provide high-quality data that have been rarely obtained, by using high-speed optical methods with high resolutions (50,000 frames per second), while using a combined analytical and numerical method to help elucidate the physics and heat transfer mechanism in the meniscus region.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, the underlying phenomena at work during heat transfer in the contact line region was studied. This was done by studying stable and oscillating menisci which are formed on a heated surface. Experiments were conducted to determine evaporation rates in stable and oscillating menisci. The influence of substrate properties and their effect on meniscus behavior and heat transfer was also investigated. An interferometric measurement system was designed and manufactured to obtain the temporal evolution of the liquid film thickness in a receding meniscus. A linear relationship between the receding contact and the heater surface temperature was observed. The surface roughness was also found to influence the contact line velocity with increasing surface roughness leading to decreased contact line movement. Enhanced surfaces which utilize the influence of contact region heat transfer were developed to generate additional contact line regions under nucleating bubbles with the use of microgrooves. Significant performance enhancement in critical heat flux and heat transfer coefficient was achieved with these enhanced surfaces during boiling tests. Tubular pool boiling surface enhancements were adapted from the flat surface microchannels to also take advantage of the contact region heat transfer. The effect of substrate properties on critical heat flux and heat transfer coefficient during pool boiling was established. Studying heat transfer and movement at the contact line region of a meniscus is expected to help better understand microlayer contact line region heat transfer during boiling. The results of the work have been published in reputed journals (International Journal of Heat and Mass Transfer, Journal of Heat Transfer, and Applied Physics Letters) as well as at major conferences in the US (International Conference on Nanochannels, Microchannels and Minichannels, July 2016 and International Mechanical Engineering Conference and Exposition, November 2016). A group of undergraduate and graduate students were trained to design, fabricate, and test the experimental systems. They gained further insight from the data collection and data analysis processes. The students performed advanced experiments through the graduate level courses offered in support of the project. In addition to their efforts made towards the project, these students also volunteered at the E3 fair, a program founded by the PI now in its 28th year which is geared towards middle school students. Students participate in science exhibits and build working machines capable of performing predefined tasks. The PI’s group additionally participated in ‘Beyond 9.8’- which is a program for 4th-6th grade students from Theodore Roosevelt School #43 school are introduced to the research taking place in the various research groups at RIT. 


Last Modified: 08/28/2018
Modified by: Satish G Kandlikar
